questions.question:
Which of the following suffices to convert an arbitrary CFG to an LL(1) grammar?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
C.

Removing left recursion and factoring the grammar
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
If the strings of a language L can be effectively enumerated in lexicographic (i.e. alphabetic) order, which of the following statements is true?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
B.

L is regular but not necessarily finite

C.

L is context free but not necessarily regular

D.

L is recursive but not necessarily context free
questions.correct_answer:
D.

L is recursive but not necessarily context free
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Nobody knows yet if P = NP. Consider the language L defined as follows : \(L=\left\{\begin{matrix} (0+1)^{*}\; \; \; if P=NP\\ \Phi \; \; otherwise \end{matrix}\right.\)
Which of the following statements is true ?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
B.

L is recursively enumerable but not recursive

D.

Whether L is recursive or not will be known after we find out if P = NP
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
The C language is :

(GATE CSE 2002)
options:
D.

Parsable fully only by a Turing machine
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following is true ?

(GATE CSE 2002)
options:
A.

The complement of a recursive language is recursive.

B.

The complement of a recursively enumerable language is recursively enumerable.

C.

The complement of a recursive language is either recursive or recursively enumerable.

D.

The complement of a context-free language is context-free.
questions.correct_answer:
A.

The complement of a recursive language is recursive.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
What can be said about a regular language L over {a} whose minimal finite state automaton has two states?

(GATE CSE 2000)
options:
D.

Either L must be\(\{a^n \mid n \text{ is odd}\}\), or L must be \(\{a^n \mid n \text{ is even}\}\)
questions.correct_answer:
D.

Either L must be\(\{a^n \mid n \text{ is odd}\}\), or L must be \(\{a^n \mid n \text{ is even}\}\)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow
